Literature Review: In recent years, the field of survival analysis has experienced significant advancements, particularly in the context of high-dimensional data. This progress has been driven by the increasing availability of large-scale datasets in precision medicine and the need for more sophisticated analytical tools to handle complex time-to-event outcomes. This literature review aims to explore the current state of high-dimensional survival analysis, focusing on methodological developments and their applications in medical research.Traditional survival analysis methods, such as Cox proportional hazards models, have long been the cornerstone of time-to-event data analysis. However, these classical approaches face significant challenges when dealing with high-dimensional data, where the number of predictors far exceeds the number of observations. Li et al. (2019) highlighted this issue, demonstrating that conventional methods often lead to overfitting and poor predictive performance in high-dimensional settings.To address these limitations, researchers have developed various feature selection techniques specifically tailored for survival data. Tibshirani (1997) introduced the Lasso (Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator) method for the Cox model, which performs simultaneous variable selection and parameter estimation. This approach has been widely adopted and extended in subsequent studies. For instance, Simon et al. (2011) proposed the adaptive Lasso for the Cox model, which assigns different penalties to different coefficients, potentially improving variable selection accuracy.Another prominent approach in high-dimensional survival analysis is the use of machine learning techniques. Random survival forests, introduced by Ishwaran et al. (2008), extend the popular random forest algorithm to right-censored survival data. This method has shown excellent predictive performance in various applications, including cancer prognosis studies. More recently, deep learning approaches have gained traction in survival analysis. Katzman et al. (2018) developed DeepSurv, a deep neural network for personalized treatment recommendations that can handle high-dimensional, non-linear data.Feature screening methods have also emerged as powerful tools for dimensionality reduction in survival analysis. Fan et al. (2010) proposed sure independence screening (SIS) for ultrahigh-dimensional feature spaces, which has been adapted for various survival models. These methods aim to reduce the feature space to a more manageable size while retaining the most informative predictors.The integration of omics data in survival analysis has opened new avenues for understanding complex diseases. Yuan et al. (2014) developed a method for integrating multi-omics data in survival prediction, demonstrating improved prognostic accuracy compared to single-omics approaches. This highlights the potential of high-dimensional survival analysis in leveraging diverse data types for more comprehensive disease modeling.Competing risks, where subjects may experience multiple distinct types of events, present additional challenges in survival analysis. Fine and Gray (1999) introduced the subdistribution hazards model for competing risks data, which has been extended to high-dimensional settings. For example, Fu et al. (2017) proposed a variable selection method for the Fine-Gray model in high-dimensional competing risks data.Applications of high-dimensional survival analysis have been particularly impactful in cancer research. The Boston Lung Cancer Survival Cohort study, as mentioned in the abstract, exemplifies the use of these advanced methods in large-scale epidemiological studies. Similar applications have been reported in other cancer types, such as breast cancer (van 't Veer et al., 2002) and glioblastoma (Zhao et al., 2019).Despite these advancements, several challenges remain in high-dimensional survival analysis. The interpretability of complex machine learning models, the handling of missing data, and the incorporation of time-varying covariates are areas that require further research. Additionally, the development of user-friendly software implementations is crucial for the wider adoption of these methods in clinical research.In conclusion, high-dimensional survival analysis has evolved rapidly in recent years, driven by the needs of precision medicine and the availability of large-scale datasets. The integration of feature selection techniques, machine learning approaches, and competing risks models has significantly enhanced our ability to analyze complex time-to-event data. As the field continues to advance, we can expect further innovations that will improve our understanding of disease progression and treatment outcomes, ultimately contributing to more personalized and effective healthcare strategies.
